elements.text: PART ONE
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
Scene 1: EXT. ALIEN BEACH
AN IDYLLIC PLANET OF LEISURE, RELAXATION AND ENJOYMENT. TROPICAL
GUITAR MUSIC, SURF, EXOTIC BIRD SONG. THE DOCTOR AND FLIP
SUNNING THEMSELVES, LYING IN HAMMOCKS ON A SLEEPY BEACH.
CREAK GENTLY IN THE BREEZE.
(SIGHS CONTENTEDLY) Aaah...
What was that, Doctor?

Nothing, just ‘aaah’. Bliss, Flip, perfect bliss, no rabid creatures trying to pull the universe from under our feet, no monsters, no Daleks yelling ‘ex-ter-minate’! This planet is well named, Tranquillity; that is just what it delivers. Yes, ahh... (SIGHS WITH SWEET CONTENTMENT) .. tranquillity.
Doctor...?
Mmm?
How long have we been here, exactly?
Flip, time no longer matters, it has no relevance; we can stay here for as long as we wish.
Yeah, but how long’s that gonna be?
I have absolutely no idea. The universe can get by without us for a few hours. Days. Aeons.
Aeons!?!
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 3

Right now, I wish for nothing more than this sun, this sand... this hammock, swaying softly in this gentle breeze... and another refreshing glass of ‘Delicia’. (RATTLE OF ICE, DRINKS) Ahh. That’s the ticket.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 4
Scene 2: INT. CONCORP — BOARDROOM
THE ROOM IS WAY UP INSIDE A TALL BUILDING. THERE IS LITTLE TRAFFIC
APART FROM THE FAINT WHOOSHING SOUNDS OF THE SKY CAR NETWORK IN THE SKY ABOVE. SIL AND PRESIDENT BOSCOE ARE ARGUING FIERCELY.
No, Mr President, NO! You have exceeded your credit limit. I cannot countenance a further loan!
My dear Sil... The Universal Monetary Fund exists to service requests such as this.
But not to submit to excessive demands without guarantees! No, Mr President. Concorp has come to my well once too often.
My request is on behalf of Concorpia. You are supporting not just a corporation, but a country, a nation!
I have already put myself in jeopardy with my masters on Thoros Beta. I have recommended billions of credits in loans. My masters wish to know when and how you propose to pay them back?
We plan further austerity measures.
Only radical cutting will do. You pay too much in benefits to the general population, to non-productive people.
I thought you had a plan. That little side project you’ve been working on in the Concorp medical centre...?
That is private business! It has nothing to do with the U.M.F.!

Of course, of course. (SLY) But it would be personally compromising, would it not, were your U.M.F. masters to hear about the little venture you’ve embarked upon, using Concorp’s facilities? They might well perceive a conflict of interest.
My dear President Boscoe, there is no need to resort to idle threats.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 5
They are not idle. I need a further influx of funds to keep our national budget viable.
Well, how much more do you require?
Twelve billion universal credits.
(SPLUTTERS IN SHOCK) Twe.. Twel.. Twelve?! Do you jest?
Should I approach one of your rivals, then? Perhaps Mistress Na will prove more... flexible.
SOFTENS HIS STANCE EVEN MORE.

Mr President, our association has long been of mutual benefit. There is no need for us to fall out over such a trivial amount. But should the U.M.F. reject your request, I trust you will appreciate that I have already lent you far more than my personal discretion allows...?
Enough of your snivelling, Sil. I must have re-financing. Do you wish for the population of Concorpia to rise up against us?
The proletariat? (SHUDDERS) Nobody wants that, Mr President.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 6
Scene 3: EXT. ALIEN BEACH THE DOCTOR SNORES GENTLY IN TIME TO THE ROLLING SURF.
Doctor, your coat’s on fire.
(SLEEPILY) Not to worry...
(LOUD) I said, your coat’s on fire!!!
(SUDDENLY AWAKE) What?! Wh— aaah!
FX: HAMMOCK CREAKS HEAVILY AS HE FALLS OUT OF IT WITH A CRASH,
SPILLING AND UPSETTING HIS DRINKS TABLE.
Very funny. Now look what you’ve made me do, you’ve made me spill my jug of Delicia!
Good.
Good?!
Yes, good — you, you hammock potato!
I’ve merely become, how would you say — chilled? Laid back?
Laid out, more like.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 7
Scene 4: INT. CONCORP — COMMUNICATIONS CENTRE
BOB, A LACONIC TECHIE, IS TRYING TO ESTABLISH AN INTERPLANETARY
LINK WITH SIL’S HOME PLANET. THERE IS STATIC AND A JUMBLE OF INTER-GALACTIC NOISE.
What is happening? I wish to call Thoros-beta.
Should’ve booked it earlier.
FX: STATIC RESOLVES ITSELF.
There we go. Ugh, horrible distort on the picture, mind.
There, on the screen, that is my master, the Lord Mav.
That’s how he looks? That wrinkly old lizard?
The Lord Mav, yes.
I can’t sit looking at that; (GETTING UP) I’m off on my break.
But I cannot hear what he is saying!
(LEAVING) Press the speaker switch. (MUTTER) Put me right off my tea.
Speaker switch... Ah!
FX: BLIP. MAV CUTS IN MID-SPEECH; HE IS AN ANCIENT THOROS-BETAN
WITH A REEDY QUAVERY VOICE THAT HAS A SLIGHT DISTORTED QUALITY BECAUSE OF THE INTER-PLANETARY WOBBLE EFFECT.
(D) [Sil! Sil! Are] you listening to me, Sil?!
I am here, my Lord Mav. I hear you!
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 8

(D) At last. I was beginning to feel ignored. Now — I have received your request for yet more funds. Fourteen billion credits! After an initial loan of one trillion to this... Concorpia. Are you gambling with U.M.F. money, Sil?
Perish the thought, Ancient Master.
(D) ‘Concorpia’. Do I know them? Weren’t they once called something else? The — ‘Yuk’, is that right?
The U.K., my Lord. Or ‘not so Great Britain’.
(D) Oh, yes, we accepted their crown jewels as part of the bankruptcy settlement. Why are we interested in this tiny island, anyway? (SUSPICIOUS) Just what are you doing there, Sil?
Concorp manufactures and exports P.P.M.C. drugs to the rest of the planet, my Lord.
(D) P.P.M.-what?
Population Pacification and Mind Control. An industry that could bring great prosperity to us as investors.
(D) Ah, my second favourite word, next to profit. Mm, pros-per- ity, mm, pro-fit. Lovely. Well, go on.

I can vouch for the integrity of Concorp, they have matters well in hand. Their society is stable, the people are docile. There are no political parties to worry about, just a President and a like- minded Board who govern the country.
(D) Do they have any competition?
Only an East World conglomerate state, Hang Seng, controlled so ably by my esteemed colleague, Mistress Na. But their research is lagging far behind that of Concorp, thanks to my guidance.
(D) Then explain to my dull mind why, even with your sage advice, this Concorp outfit is so deeply in debt?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 9
They have a large non-productive population, the work is mostly done by elite members of Concorp. Did you receive my analysis, Master?
(D) I did, Sil. (READING OFF SCREEN) G.N.P., eighty-five per cent; no monopoly markets; unemployment seventy-one per cent; .. against
a fourteen billion credit loan?! No, I cannot allow that amount.
Master, please...
(D) Not in full. Twelve billion credits is the maximum I can authorise at this time, but only if the loan repayment rate is increased by a further two per cent.
Thank you, wise Lord Mav. I will put that to them.

(D) Discipline, Sil; probity; integrity must be your watchword with these foreign creatures. You must instruct them in the ways of finance that has made Thoros Beta supreme. Others may wish to conquer all known worlds, but why bother when we can buy them up and take them over? (CACKLES AND WHEEZES)
FX: MESSAGE CUTS OFF.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 10
Scene 5: EXT. ALIEN BEACH
FX: AS BEFORE
SIGHS HEAVILY
What is it? What’s the matter?
It’s just — (ANOTHER SIGH)
Am I to take it, Miss Jackson, that you are bored?
Tranquillity’s not exactly my scene, Doctor.
Well, what would be more your scene, Flip? Bungee-jumping off the Colossus of Rhodes? Off-roading through the Hanging Gardens of Babylon? Free-diving to the ruins of Atlantis?
All right, no need to get — Hang about. Atlantis? Seriously?
Depends which Atlantis, of course. There are several.
Any Atlantis. I’1ll take any Atlantis, any day [you like.])
FX: A SHRILL INSISTENT PULSING SOUND BEGINS TO BE HEARD NEARBY —
AN ALARM FROM INSIDE THE TARDIS.
What’s that racket?
(UNEASY) Oh, that, nothing; nothing at all.
It’s coming from the TARDIS.
Is it? Oh, well, even if it is, it’s nothing to worry about.
You sure? Sounds like it’s gonna self destruct or something.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 11
No, nothing like that. Just ignore it, it will soon go away. I hope.
FX: THE ALARM CONTINUES TO SOUND.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 12
Scene 6: INT. CONCORP — BOARDROOM
FX: DISTANT SKY TRAFFIC AS BEFORE. DOORS SLIDE OPEN. SIL IS BORNE
IN.
Well, Sil? Did your masters agree to the loan?
(TO BEARERS) Place me here, bearers, here! Beside Mr President! (TO BOSCOE) The U.M.F. has consented to advance Concorp a further twelve billion credits —
Good news!
. but at an increased rate of interest. Three per cent!
That’s exorbitant, impossible. We will go elsewhere, these rates are beyond extortionate!
Mr President, I quite agree. Might you be able to accept, say, two per cent extra?
Two-? (BEAT) Yes, all right, agreed.
Contingent on one further condition.
What would that be, exactly?
That you allow a representative of the U.M.F. to take a place on
your board.
Was a name suggested?
It was.
And?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 13
The name put forward was that of Sil.
What a surprise.

I will be a most valuable addition, beside you in this Boardroom. You will need my guidance to implement the stringent measures that lie ahead, will you not, Amadeus? May I call you Amadeus, since it will be my hand plucking on your purse strings?
You can call me whatever you like, just pay that loan into the
Treasury.
Right away, my dear Amadeus.
HE CHORTLES A LITTLE.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 14
Scene 7: EXT. ALIEN BEACH
FX: THE TARDIS DISTRESS CALL GROWS EVER LOUDER.
You’re not planning on sleeping through this racket?
(SLEEPILY) It will stop soon, distress signals usually do.
Distress-—? Did you say ‘distress signal’? (SHAKES HIS HAMMOCK — IT
NOISILY) Doctor, what’s going on?
Mind my hammock! — Oh, all right. Each TARDIS has a facility that sends out a distress call, for when a Time Lord finds themselves in extreme danger.
Like an SOS?
Exactly.
Shouldn’t we answer it, then?
Someone on Gallifrey is bound to have heard it by now.
Then why is the alarm still sounding?
THE ALARM BECOMES EVER MORE INSISTENT.
Just ignore it.
I I can’t stand this noise. Do something, Doctor, right now!
I Jt’s not my responsibility,!
I What’s the matter with you? You feeling your age?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 15
I am no age at all, as Time Lords go. I’m in my prime, yes, my absolute prime, absolutely.
Buried in that hammock,, you don’t create that impression.
I know, but it’s so lovely.
Where’s your sense of adventure gone? How can you be deaf to a fellow Time Lord’s cry for help?
Yes, well,— I have to admit, a couple of things are beginning to bother me.
What’s the first?
Your somewhat flippant attitude to me, young lady.
And the second?
Why has that alarm been sounding so long? Something is wery much amiss. (FX: HAMMOCK CREAKS AS HE LEAPS OUT) Right, young Flip, duty calls,! Come on, stir your, sticks!
Me-?
(HEADING TO TARDIS) No use sitting around when there’s a soul in need of saving-!
Unbelievable. (FOLLOWING HIM ACROSS SAND) Hey, wait up-!
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 16
Scene 8: INT. CONCORP — LABORATORY
IN THE B.G. ARE THE WHIRRS AND BEEPS OF COMPLEX SCIENTIFIC
EQUIPMENT.
Mistress Cordelia, what progress to report?
Your translator device needs adjustment, Sil. The term ‘mistress’ is misleading and most inaccurate.
I’ve an upgrade on order, you must make allowances... my dear.
GURGLES
Just ‘Cordelia’ will suffice for our business dealings.
Business, yes. What progress on our ‘special project’?
Nothing further since the last time you asked, which was yesterday.
This does not please me. I can have this laboratory closed, your research funding withdrawn!
Virological research is a complicated process. I am taking pains to ensure the antidote is a complete success.
Pain? You are causing me pain with your shally-shillying! [SIC]
You promised me another Time Lord. Where is he?
Moves are afoot. But please... Cordelia... try not to spoil him, the way you did the last!
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 17
Scene 9: INT. TARDIS — CONTROL ROOM
FX: TARDIS STATIONARY. ALARM CONTINUES. BLIPS AND BLEEPS AS DOCTOR
FIDDLES WITH CONTROLS.
That’s odd. The call seems to be emanating from Earth, but I can’t seem to fix the temporal co-ordinates. Let’s try again, shall we...?
(LOUD, OVER NOISE) Yeah, can you find the ‘mute’ button while you’re about it?
FX: DOCTOR CUTS ALARM.
Better?
Just a bit.
FX: BUTTON-PRESSING.
Now, those co-ordinates. There they go, spinning, spinning...
Forward or back?
Forward from your time, I think... yes, the year twenty-three eighty-two! Twenty-fourth century, can’t remember too much about that period.
I certainly can’t.
Well, there’s your call to adventure, Miss Jackson.
Let’s answer it, ay?
FX: DOCTOR BEGINS TARDIS DE-MATERIALISATION.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 18
Scene 10: INT. CONCORP — PRESIDENTIAL APARTMENT
FX: SIL IS EATING NOISILY.
(DISTASTE) How are the ‘marsh minnows’, Sil?
(MOUTH FULL) Acceptable, a trifle better than your last attempt, Mr President.
Fish are a rare commodity. I had our vitro food designers build you a replica product specially.
Won’t you be joining me?
I seem to have lost my appetite.
GOBBLES DOWN A FEW MORE THROUGH:
I must say, the meeting went well. Your ideas seemed reasonably well received by the rest of the Board.
Apart from that woman person.
Kristal? Yes, Kristal is something of a liberal recidivist; she is our voice of conscience, not to be taken account of.

Most wise, most wise, but your main economic problem remains. Too many mouths to feed, too many unearned home comforts. Their benefit payments are the reason I have been sent here to find a radical solution to resolve your dilemma.
At least civil unrest is not a factor we need concern ourselves with.
Thank the Great Morgo for that.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 19
Scene 11: INT. TUBE PLATFORM/TUNNEL
FX: SOUNDS OF TARDIS MATERIALISATION. DOOR OPENS.
Where are we?
Somewhere underground.
Not just somewhere underground. The Underground! The Tube! Where I first met you, sort of.
FX: DOCTOR CLOSES TARDIS DOOR.
I must say, Flip, you have the eyesight of a nocturnal animal. I can barely make out a thing in this gloom.
Me neither, but I’d know the smell anywhere. Oily engines and sweaty passengers, eurgh.
(RUMMAGING) Hold on, I usually keep a torch in the pockets of my coat...
That coat of yours could light the way on its own.
(PRODUCING TORCH) Ah-ha!
FX: CLICKS TORCH ON.
What did I tell you? Embankment.
I No use waiting for a train, I believe there hasn’t been one for, I quite some time.
Yeah, ‘We are sorry for the three-hundred year delay to your journey and apologise for any inconvenience this may cause.’ All I right, then: which way to the TARDIS in distress?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 20

All in hand. If you could just take the torch? — Thank you. (PRODUCING SOMETHING ELSE FROM POCKETS) We can triangulate its position by using this handy little gizmo I picked up at the Garazone Bazaar.
FX: ACTIVATES GIZMO; IT BIP-BIP-BIPS.
Yes, and what it’s telling me is we go... that-a-way.
FX: SHUTS OFF GIZMO.
What, into the tunnel? Looks dead creepy, a real rat hole.
(TEASING) Why — don’t you like rats, Miss Jackson?
It’s not that I don’t like rats. I just don’t think they’1ll like me.
Did I never tell you about the time I spent as a ratcatcher in Hamelin? (JUMPS OFF PLATFORM; CALLS UP) Come on, hop down off the platform.
FX: FLIP JUMPS ONTO THE TRACK. DUST KICKS UP.
COUGHS
Yes, ‘Dust of ages...’
Most of it in my throat. (COUGHS)
THEY START TO WALK INTO THE TUNNEL.
(WALKING) Wonder how long it’s been since these tracks were live?
(WALKING) A long time indeed, judging by the depth of oxide coating. They’re almost rusted away.
(WALKING) Rusted? Down here?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 21
(STOPPING) Well, the River Thames is directly above our heads. Without regular maintenance, moisture will soon seep through.
(COUGHS AGAIN) Moisture, yes — tell you what, Doctor, I could really use something to drink.
I’d have brought some Delicia with us, but someone made me spill the last of my supply. — Look now, there’s an opening ahead!
FX: THEY SET OFF AGAIN. CROSS TO:
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 22
Scene 12: INT. TUBE PLATFORM
FX: PAN RATTLES A SMALL CAGE.
Anything in there, Pan?
Not today. Rats are intelligent, they’re getting wise to the traps.
So hungry, Pan. It’s been days now.
You were right, Cerise. It’s no good waiting for the food to come to us, [we’ll have to go hunting. ]
FX: IN B/G, THE DOCTOR AND FLIP APPROACHING DOWN TUNNEL.
(OFF, APPROACHING — TALKING TO DOCTOR) Hang about, I thought the Piper was the bad guy?
(OFF, APPROACHING) The legend got garbled in the telling, of course. No, all was not as it seemed, in the mountains of Lower Saxony in the year 1284...
(ALARM) Pan...! Pan! There, in the tunnel! Bakerloonies!
(CALLING OUT) You two — get away, we’ve got nothing you want!
FX: THE DOCTOR AND FLIP ARE AT THE MOUTH OF THE TUNNEL.
I do beg your pardon. Is yours a private platform?
Please! It’s the end of the month, we’ve spent all our credits.
(THREATENING) You don’t belong here, get back to your own line!
You mean, like the Bakerloo line?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin
Yes, where else?
This is the Northern line. We are Northernliners.
We have no truck with Bakerloonies.
Well, we are not of the Bakerloo persuasion.
Liar! That’s what Bakerloonies do — lie and cheat, sneak
tunnels, steal our food and water.
Water, you have water?
Not fresh. Only bottled.
Even better.
Look, do you mind if we come up onto the platform?
Watch him, Pan.
FX: DOCTOR CLIMBS UP ONTO PLATFORM.
down
Page 23
We mean you no harm. We’re searching for a fellow traveller who may be in serious trouble. But if you could spare my young friend
a little water, it would be much appreciated.
FX: FLIP CLIMBS UP AFTER DOCTOR.
Just leave it, Doctor. I’1l go without.
“Doctor”?
Give the girl some water, Cerise.
You’re sure?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 24
If they were Bakerloonies, they wouldn’t ask, they’d take. Besides — look at her, she’s desperate, she’s ready to tox out. [IE,
SHE’S AN ADDICT]
All right... Here, catch!
FX: SHE THROWS A HALF-EMPTY PLASTIC BOTTLE AT FLIP. SLOSHES.
(CATCHING IT) Whoa!
Have the lot, it’s nearly empty.
Are you sure-?
We only kept it for emergencies.
Cheers, then. (DRINKS) Oh, that is so good... Mm, thank you. (OFFERING BOTTLE) Doctor...?
No, thank you. I’m still full of Delicia.
Are you really a doctor?
Well...
I’m a doctor. Well, at least I was a doctor — until they brought in robo-scans.
‘They’, being?
Concorp, of course. I was a pharmacist, until Concorp closed down all non-company outlets. What’s she to you, the girl?
Miss Jackson is — well, you could call her my assistant.
Like a nurse?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 25
(HAVING DRAINED BOTTLE) Some of the time, yeah. Oh, that’s better.
You’1ll be on your way now, then?
Yes, I think so.
Way Out’s at the far end of the platform. The stairs’1ll take you above ground.
Yes — now we’re on the other side of the river, above ground is
where we need to be. Ready, Flip?
Ready? Me?
(ODD) Yes, you.
Me, I’m ready. I’m ever ready, me. (SHE GIGGLES FOR NO REASON)
Are you quite all right, Miss Jackson?
Never better!
(SLIGHT DISGUST) Now she’s had her water fix.
Exactly! (GIGGLES) Lead on, Doc.
FX: THEY WALK. CROSS TO:
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 26
Scene 13: INT. TUBE — IMMOBILE ESCALATOR UP
FX: FADE UP THE DOCTOR AND FLIP TRUDGING UP STEPS.
(PUFFING) A couple of centuries back, I’d have scaled this escalator like a mountain goat. (CALLING BACK) You were right, Flip — I’m a Time Lord, not a beach bum.
(STOPS, SPACED OUT) Beach bum. Cool. You are so cool, Doctor.
(STOPPED) If anything, I’m a little overheated.
(GIGGLES) You’re dead funny, too.
Cool, dead and funny? Well, it wouldn’t be much of an epitaph, but it’d do. Come on, not much further now. I think I see daylight.
FX: HE STARTS TO CLIMB THE STAIRS AGAIN — THEN STOPS, TURNS.
Flip? This is no place for a sit-down. Once we’re above ground, I can recalibrate the location of this TARDIS in distress.
I was just thinking — we’re so lucky, Doctor. So very very lucky.
Flip? Is something the matter?
(DREAMILY) No, no. I just want to sit here and think about how lucky we are. Don’t you think we’re lucky, Doctor?
Being stuck on a broken-down escalator covered in several centuries’ worth of accumulated grime is not my idea of luck.
But it’s so high. It’s amazing.
Flip, look at me. Open your eyes, wide, wider. Yes, as I thought. (HAULING HER UP) Come on, let’s get you up on your feet.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 27
(FLOPPY) Just leave me here, Doctor. I want to chill.
Up the stairs, young lady! Move!
FX: HE DRAGS HER UP. CROSS TO:
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 28
Scene 14: EXT. WATERLOO STATION
FX: FADE UP HEAVY RAIN. SOME DISTANT RIVER TRAFFIC AND THE
WHOOSH OF A SKY CAR AS THE DOCTOR AND FLIP EMERGE FROM UNDERGROUND.
Where’s the fire, Doctor? You need to relax. — (REALISATION) Oh wow. Rain. I love the rain, don’t you?
Flip, listen to me. I think the water you were given back there must have been contaminated.
Whatever.
Contaminated with a sedative of some sort, maybe even a psychotropic drug. Whatever it contained is affecting your personality; your perception, too.
BEAT.
Pffaww, I feel just great. Have you seen, it’s raining? Rain, wow!
It’s nothing to get excited about. Now: whatever this poison is, we need to flush it out of your system, fast. — (REALISATION) It’s raining!
I told you..! Isn’t it amazeballs?
Rainwater, that’s what we need. Here, Flip — you see that
drainpipe? I’m going to pull it off the wall.
Ooh, you rebel!
FX: DOCTOR TUGGING AT DRAINPIPE. SCRAPING AGAINST BRICK.
It’s not vandalism, it’s a medical emergency-!
FX: FIXING GIVES WAY; WATER COMES POURING OUT OF GUTTER ABOVE, IN
A TORRENT.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin
There, that’s got it.
It’s like a waterfall... Cool.
Page 29
Isn’t it just. (STEERING HER) And you, young lady, are in urgent
need of a very ‘cool’ shower!
Don’t be silly.
(SHOVING HER) Under you go!
(SHOVED UNDER TORRENT) What-? Doctor,
Open your mouth! Drink! Drink as much as you can! it will flush away any mind affecting residue.
(SPLUTTERS) Doctor, please —
Drink!!!
FX: CROSS FROM TORRENT OF WATER TO:
no — (CHOKES AND SPLUTTERS )
It’s pure water,
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 30
Scene 15: INT. CONCORP — EXECUTIVE SAUNA
£X: SIL BEING BATHED BY ONE OF HIS ATTENDANTS. SOUND OF WATER
HIS PERSON.
(ECSTASY) Ah, ooo, yes, yes, yes, yes! Again, servant, pour it over me again...(MORE WATER IS POURED ON HIM) Yes, oh yes —- not

too quickly, you dolt! I wish to see how my skin glistens and sparkles, such a lovely shade of green, deeply verdant and lustrous. (MORE WATER) Oh, argg, oooh! (PLEASURE), Such perfect, volcanic mineral water. Pity it costs so much to have it tankered in from the planet Tigus... but sooner that than imbibe so much as a Single drop from the pulbic water supply, hmm? (BEAT) More, slave! More! (GURGLES)
FX: FADE.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 31
Scene 16: EXT. SOUTH BANK
FX: FADE UP RIVER BACKGROUND. THE RAIN HAS STOPPED. SKY CARS ZOOM
ACROSS THE SKY FROM TIME TO TIME.
A SOOTHING FEMALE VOICE IS PLAYING ABOVE WHERE THE DOCTOR AND FLIP
SEATED.
VOICE

. You are seated opposite the place where democracy died one hundred and fourteen years ago, along with the politicians that had brought ruin to the nation formerly known as the United Kingdom. How fortunate that a company of Concorp’s stature and integrity was able to buy up the nation’s last remaining assets [in order to revitalise not only the economy, but also the happiness of all the people. Concorp loves you. ]
COMES AWAKE WITH A START.
What, where — what’s that voice?
Back with us, Miss Jackson-? Good.
Oh, I’m soaking. — Hang about, isn’t this the South Bank?

In your time, perhaps. Here in the twenty-fourth century, it appears to be part of what’s known as the Westminster theme park — as this rather handy tourist information post has been telling me, repeatedly, throughout the time you’ve been asleep.
Asleep? Have I been out of it long?
Long enough. The water you were given contained a cocktail of drugs that distorted your sense of reality.
Those two freaks in the underground — they gave me spiked water! Why?

I’m not sure. But while I’ve been sitting here waiting for you to recover your senses I’ve been watching the people passing by, all of them with happy grins on their faces, all praising the beauty of the riverside.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 32
Beauty? It’s a complete dump! Look at the river, it’s all choked up with rubbish!

NO REPRISE
Scene 20: INT. CONCORP — CELL

(SUDDENLY AWAKE) Ah! Doctor? Doctor, there you are! Oh, Doctor — I had the most terrible dream. I drank this dodgy water and then, like, we were in the House of Commons with this horrible sort of slug-man thing who had us both shot!
For a time, I imagined I was back on Tranquillity. Alas, when I woke up, I was stuck here with you in this cell.
Cell? You mean —
You have rather less of an imagination than I do, young lady. Unfortunately, it seems that Sil had his guards’ guns set to stun, not to kill.
What do you mean, ‘unfortunately’?
I mean that whatever Sil has planned for us, it can only be worse
than death.
Worse? How?
FX: HEAVY DOOR CLUNKS OPEN.
I imagine we’re about to find out.
SIL, CARRIED BY HIS BEARERS, ENTERS.
Place me down opposite to the prisoners. Not too near, out of their reach, you oafs! — yes, here, so I can gaze at our guests in
perfect safety. (BEAT) Doctor. What a sublime pleasure to meet with you once more.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 39
The feeling is not reciprocated, Sil.
Where are we? What are you going to do to us?

Your new home is here in the research laboratories at Concorp HQ, where you will shortly donate your repulsive persons to the advancement of medical science. (GURGLES WITH PLEASURE) How fortunate, Doctor, that it should have been you who chose to answer my call.
Your call? So where’s Anzor?
Your fellow Time Lord is also in... custody. (LAUGHS)
Sil — that’s your name, right? Shouldn’t you be looking for a stone to crawl back under?
Your new little friend fails to amuse me, Doctor. Haven’t you told her what happened to your last female companion? — now what was her name? Terry? Jerry? Merry? Not so merry at the finish, eh?
Her name was Peri.
And where is she now, Doctor? Hm?
Te
FX: CORDELIA ENTERS, WITH TWO GUARDS IN ATTENDANCE.
Sil? I’m ready to begin.
(TAKING THE MICKEY) Ah, here we go.. A woman in a white coat. She come to take you away, has she Sil?
Allow me to introduce Miss Cordelia, in charge of this laboratory.
So this is the infamous Doctor. The girl, who is she?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 40
Her name is Phillipa Jackson.
Flip for short.
Fascinating. Guards — bring them through to the laboratory hub.
After you.
No, after you.
Females first.
Ladies first, you dummy.
Whatever, move her along.
FX: ALL SHUFFLE OUT, INTO:
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 41
Scene 21: INT. CONCORP — LABORATORY [CONTINUOUS ]
FX: B/G AS BEFORE.
Your laboratory seems remarkably well-equipped, Miss Cordelia. It reminds me of that time I was in Geneva with that doctor — oh, what was his name...?
Is this really the time for one of your reminiscences, Doctor?
. Frankenstein, that was it.
Very amusing.
Tell me, what’s it all in aid of?
You Time Lords have a natural immunity to a great many of the diseases at large in the microbial universe.
We’re a resilient bunch, that much is true.
I intend to break you down, piece by genetic piece, to isolate each and every one of those immunities.
For what purpose? To combat some disease? Is there an epidemic?
Not yet.
Why the Doctor? Why not this ‘Anzor’?
The female really is as stupid as she seems.
I thought Anzor had been transported back to the antediluvian Swamps. What did you do to him, Sil?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 42
We used data records taken from his TARDIS to unlock his time transmission settings and recall him to the present. He was a most unwilling participant in our research project, alas for him.
What did you do?
Owing to a malfunction within the isolation chamber, Anzor suffered some cellular transmogrification.
He emerged not in the form he went in. (CHUCKLES)
So you used his TARDIS, to help you summon another Time Lord?
Not any other Time Lord, Doctor. Before he went in the chamber, Anzor was keen to explain to us how we might target a distress call at your TARDIS, in particular.
Charming. You mean he tried to bargain the Doctor’s life for his own?
That’d be true to form.
Well, whatever he got, it sounds like he deserved it.
The Time Lord known as Anzor was indeed a repulsive specimen.
What was it he called you, Miss Cordelia? ‘Witch’, that was it. ‘Harpy.’ ‘Harridan.’
Amongst other discriminatory terms, unacceptable in civilised society.
Sounds a right laugh.
Would you like to meet him?
Not really.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 43
Oh, but I’m sure the Doctor would. Cordelia, show the Doctor the present state of his fellow Time Lord.
(CROSSING TO WALL) Now where did I put him?

(COLLECTING BOX) Ah, yes — here he is, hiding amongst the toxin
samples.

See for yourselves.

ANZOR Fiddlesticks! Fiddlesticks!

Ugh! How the-?!

There.
That is Anzor?

How did this happen?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 44
A malfunction of the chromosomes whilst he was inside the isolation chamber. It is unlikely to occur again.
Fortunate for you, Doctor, that the mistake was made on Anzor — Since you are the next in line to enter Cordelia’s chamber of horror!
Guards! Prepare these two for decontamination!

That’s horribibble! [SIC]
(GURGLES) Cordelia, may I beg a favour? May I keep Anzor as a pet?
He is of no further use to me.

ANZOR Fiddlesticks! Fiddlesticks!

That’s for you, Sil.
Oh, what is it now? (CHECKING COMMS UNIT) It appears that President Boscoe has called an Extraordinary Board Meeting. I must attend.

Well, don’t let us stop you.
I will go at once. Bearers, lift... Not too quickly, you doltards! Cordelia, do not start the infective procedures until I return.
They will be prepped and ready...
Oh, I will look forward to that. (LAUGHS AS HE IS BORNE AWAY)
Guards! Come on, get to it!

Cordelia, you are clearly a hugely intelligent young woman. And I warn you: whatever he’s promised you, this association with Sil will bring you [no good]
Be quiet! I know all about you, Doctor; your twisted tongue, your devious mind.
I beg your pardon?
Whatever it is you’re about to say, I know full well that it is designed to deceive me.
You sure you’ve got the right Doctor?
Exactly the right Doctor. A coward who I’ve long wished to destroy.
What?!
(TO GUARDS) Decontaminate them!
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 46
Scene 22: INT. CONCORP — BOARDROOM
FX: ANOTHER BOARD MEETING IN PROGRESS.
Emergency? Great Morgo, give me strength! The only words I seem to I hear in this Boardroom are crisis and emergency!
Because that is exactly what we are faced with.
Do, please, enlighten me, Mr President.

A trade dispute has escalated into a crisis. We are running short of the drug narcoplaximine. We have only a few days supply remaining. Unless we can maintain a sufficient level in the public water supply millions of angry sleepers will awaken.
The Gen-Pop will see things as they really are.
Turn against the Consumer Corporation [FULL NAME FOR CONCORP]; seek bloody revenge against those who have fed them dreams and visions of unreality.
(ALARM) Oh dear. Are we well protected?
Not against the will of the people.
Nothing could withstand their anger.
(SOME PANIC) Purchase the drug, manufacture it, obtain supplies! We can’t allow the proles to get above themselves!

We suspect Hang Seng agents are behind the recent sabotage of our pharma factories. We also believe they are creating a worldwide shortage of the drug we seek. They wish to foment revolution so as to bring Concorp to ruin. To cover the shortfall in our drug supply until production can resume will require a further loan of three billion credits.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 47
Three?!
That is the price your colleague, Mistress Na, demands.
What was done with the last load of credits I authorised?
Spent on the status quo, and repaying exorbitant U.M.F. loan rates.
Preposterous, my masters will not countenance another request.
Need they know?

They will when they review my account at month’s end. Reckoning will pour down upon poor Sil then. Unless... yes, I would have to explain the situation, explain how I think such a loan could be repaid, how Concorp could regain solvency. Yes, yes... but I would have to propose a truly radical solution to solve your chronic insolvency. My masters would welcome that.
How radical?
Something I have been working on for just such an emergency Situation. A scheme to drastically reduce your parasitical population.
How? We can’t starve them.
Well, of course not! It would take far too long. No, the quickest
means is introduce them to our old friends, pestilence and plague!
FX: REACTIONS OF SHOCK AROUND THE TABLE...
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 48
Scene 23: INT. CONCORP — LABORATORY
FX: THE SOUND OF AN ELECTRONIC SHOWER IN OPERATION — WATER-FREE,
PARTICLES.
I’m all atingle, what’s this thing doing to us?
We’re undergoing a thorough cleansing. This is an electronic particle dispenser, designed to cleanse us of all known germs.
I’ve never taken a shower with my clothes on before.
It seems our ‘Miss Cordelia’ wants us free of infection — presumably so she can then re-infect us with whatever nasties she likes, under laboratory conditions.
The way she looks at us — those cold blue eyes... She doesn’t think much of me but she really seems to have it in for you, Doctor.
I can’t imagine why. I’ve never met her before, I’m sure of that. That said, there is something oddly familiar about her...
FX: THE SOUND OF THE ELECTRONIC SHOWER CEASES.
(SLIGHTLY OFF) Bring them through.
(EXITING INTO MAIN AREA) Well, here we are, scrubbed up and squeaky clean.
You could eat your dinner off us.
Guards — escort the subjects to the isolation chamber.
(SHOVED) Ow, who you pushing...?
No point resisting, Flip, we are entirely helpless. Completely in the power of Miss Cordelia... what did you say your name was again?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 49
You don’t know who I am, do you?
I’m afraid not.
Look closer, then. It’s often said I have my father’s eyes.
Your father-? Did I know him at all?
More than that, Doctor. You were the person responsible for my father’s death!
You what-?
My full name is Cordelia Clare Crozier.
(REMEMBERING) ‘Crozier’..?
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 50
Scene 24: INT. CONCORP — BOARDROOM
Fellow members of this Board, I regret to inform you that soon, Concorpia may well suffer outbreak after outbreak of certain... unpleasant diseases.
What sort of diseases?

Alien diseases, against which humankind has no immunity. Fortunately, and under my own expert supervision, a young scientist based within this very building is busy harvesting a number of protective vaccines.
Antigens to protect all necessary members of our society.
Such as?
Those of us on this Board, for example. Everybody else, however...
. what, dies? How can this be contemplated? Mr President?
Not every last member of the Gen Pop would perish, Kristal.
I estimate forty-five per cent —
(‘THAT MANY?!’) Forty-five?!?
. would survive the initial outbreaks. There would be a second wave, of course, to mop up that many again.
Concorpia can tolerate a rump ten per cent of especially fit individuals, for unskilled labour.
(GRUMBLES) That figure still seems a little high to me.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 51
Scene 25: INT. CONCORP — LABORATORY
Is it true, Doctor? Did you know Cordelia’s dad?
Young Crozier? — I met him, certainly, on the planet of the Mentors. A quite brilliant brain surgeon, who sought to conquer Death itself.
Which is why you had him killed!
Hardly. Cordelia, my dear young lady, I’m afraid you’ve been terribly misinformed. And I can guess by whom.
Sil.
Exactly.
And now you presume to slander my guardian!
Your what?
It was Sil who sponsored me after my father’s execution. It was Sil who paid for the education that ensured I might live up to my father’s name!
I admit, my recall of those days is a little hazy, but whatever your father’s fate, he was not ‘executed’. And certainly not at my behest!
Oh, so your ‘recall of those days is a little hazy’? How convenient.
Gotta admit, Doctor, that does sound pretty weak.
As a matter of fact, my brain was somewhat scrambled after an intimate encounter with one of young Crozier’s mind-warping machines!
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 52
A feeble pretence at amnesia. Oh, how I longed for you to answer Anzor’s distress call. Longed? I ached for it. Wherever my father is now, he will look down and rejoice at your being delivered to me.
I was removed from the scene by my own people, Ms Crozier. Whatever occurred afterwards, I wasn’t there!

Your people were simply protecting their own. In the chaos that followed their manipulation of the Laws of Time, they created a void. That was how my father died: sucked into a timeless absence, never to return!
I have only fragments of memory from that time. And I’1l have you know, Cordelia, that I, too, lost someone when the Time Lords intervened.
This ‘Peri’, right?
My companion, yes.
Sil said. What happened? She died, right?
Not exactly. It’s — well, it’s complicated.
What kind of explanation is that?

Complicate things all you like, Doctor, I know the truth. You were the Time Lords’ agent. You owe me — and you’1l repay your debt by donating your body — and that of your ‘companion’ too — to the cause of scientific research!
Me? His ‘companion’? Nah. It’s just friends. Really.
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 53
Scene 26: INT. CONCORP — BOARDROOM
Mr President? Am I to understand you knew about this alien creature’s monstrous scheme?
You must appreciate, Kristal; as President, I must be prepared to think the unthinkable when it comes to protecting our beloved Concorpia.
(LOST FOR WORDS) But how could — how could you even — [contemplate]
Titan cholera can be introduced into the public water supply; rats can be infected with a bacterium christened the New Black Death.
That’s not what I meant.
Sil, how long before the various antigens become available?

Soon, Mr President. We have very special individual assisting us. A non-human prepared to donate his body to science in the interest of reducing the cost of welfare benefits by ninety per cent. Grant me permission to proceed and I will allow Concorp a further loan on my own authority.
Shall we take a vote?
(ROLLING EYES) Democracy!
Say ‘aye’ and I shall authorise Sil to expedite this most radical of solutions.
SLIGHT PAUSE
What is your decision? ‘Aye’ or ‘nay’? Speak!
MEMBERS [NOT KRISTAL]
MUMBLE ‘AYE’
ANTIDOTE TO OBLIVION by Philip Martin Page 54
I can’t quite hear you.
MEMBERS [NOT KRISTAL] AYE!

Scene 27: INT. CONCORP — LABORATORY
Ms Crozier — Miss Jackson here is my assistant, a fellow human being not in any way involved with our mutual history, whatever that may be. Let her go.
How she responds to the viral bombardment, how soon she succumbs will be of value to the project.
Doctor, I don’t much fancy this. I know I said I wanted an adventure, but being some mad woman’s guinea pig comes way down the list.

You are the main prize, Doctor. As you do battle with the diseases that await you in the isolation chamber, my instruments will track the resistance your immune system summons up to resist the viral onslaught.
What sort of diseases do you mean? Cos I’m rubbish with a sniffle. One sneeze and I’m dead for a week.

I think Ms Crozier has more than the common cold in mind. They’re all lined up on the bench here, in vials. (READING) Cholerae Titanicum; a nasty little flavivirus from the Outer Galaxies; Yersinia pestis novus?! You are spoiling us.
They’re not what you think. Merely failed attempts at a panacea. Guards, keep him away from the samples.
Why? If these are failures, there’s no harm in picking up this tube of ‘New Black Death’ — (GRABS VIAL) — is there now?
Put that back, Doctor.
But it wouldn’t matter if I did drop it, and smash it open on the floor — would it, Ms Crozier? Oh — except a failed antidote would contain something of the original disease, would it not?
